Literature Review: Cephalopods, particularly coleoid cephalopods such as squids, octopuses, and cuttlefish, exhibit some of the most complex behaviors among invertebrates, supported by their highly developed nervous systems. The molecular underpinnings of these complex behaviors have been a subject of intense research, with recent studies highlighting the role of RNA editing in the neural proteome of these organisms. RNA editing, particularly adenosine-to-inosine (A→I) editing mediated by adenosine deaminase acting on RNA (ADAR) enzymes, has been identified as a significant mechanism for generating protein diversity in cephalopods. This literature review explores the extent, implications, and potential adaptive significance of RNA editing in the neural proteome of cephalopods, drawing on recent studies to provide a comprehensive overview of this fascinating area of research. Early molecular cloning studies in squid revealed an unusually high number of A→I RNA editing sites in ion channel transcripts, suggesting a unique mechanism for generating protein diversity in the nervous system of cephalopods (Rosenthal & Bezanilla, 2002). Subsequent research expanded these findings, demonstrating that RNA editing is not limited to ion channels but is widespread across the neural transcriptome of various cephalopod species (Liscovitch-Brauer et al., 2017). The advent of deep-sequencing technologies has facilitated the comprehensive mapping of RNA editing events, revealing that cephalopods possess orders of magnitude more recoding editing sites than any other known taxon (Alon et al., 2015). This extensive recoding is thought to contribute to the behavioral complexity observed in cephalopods by increasing the functional diversity of neural proteins. The majority of neural transcripts in cephalopods are subject to RNA editing, with many editing sites resulting in amino acid changes that could potentially alter protein function (Garrett & Rosenthal, 2012). This contrasts with most other multicellular organisms, where RNA editing sites are abundant but rarely result in recoding events. The high prevalence of recoding RNA editing in cephalopods raises questions about its adaptive significance. Recent studies have begun to address this question, exploring whether RNA editing in cephalopods is subject to positive selection and whether it contributes to the adaptation of these organisms to their environments (Liscovitch-Brauer et al., 2017). In addition to its potential adaptive role, RNA editing in cephalopods exhibits several noncanonical features, including the editing of non-coding RNAs and the presence of editing sites in regions of the transcriptome that are typically conserved across species (Rieder et al., 2015). These findings suggest that RNA editing in cephalopods may have unique regulatory functions beyond protein recoding. The molecular mechanisms underlying the extensive RNA editing in cephalopods are also a subject of ongoing research. ADAR enzymes, which catalyze A→I editing, are highly expressed in the nervous system of cephalopods, and their activity is thought to be regulated by both genetic and environmental factors (Palladino et al., 2000). The interplay between ADAR activity and the complex neural circuitry of cephalopods may provide insights into the evolution of RNA editing and its role in the development of complex behaviors. In conclusion, the extensive recoding of the neural proteome by RNA editing is a distinctive feature of cephalopods that may contribute to their remarkable behavioral complexity. The high prevalence of recoding editing sites, the potential adaptive significance of these events, and the noncanonical aspects of RNA editing in cephalopods are areas of active research that promise to deepen our understanding of the molecular basis of behavior in these fascinating organisms.
